docs.snippet: A T 33 Patricia McGregor is taking, in her own words, a ''big leap'' as the director of Katori Hall's ''Hurt Village,'' part of the inaugural season at the new Signature Theater complex.      Ms. McGregor lives in Harlem with her 86-year-old fathe...
docs.lead_paragraph: A T 33 Patricia McGregor is taking, in her own words, a ''big leap'' as the director of Katori Hall's ''Hurt Village,'' part of the inaugural season at the new Signature Theater complex. Ms. McGregor lives in Harlem with her 86-year-old father, Oscar, who is battling cancer, and her older sister, Paloma, a choreographer with whom she founded Angela's Pulse, an artists' collective. While she has done work across the city, from the Brooklyn Academy of Music to Lincoln Center Institute, many of her shows in recent years have been mounted uptown, at Harlem Stage and at the Apollo, where she wrote and directed a theatrical concert called ''Burnt Sugar Freaks the James Brown Songbook.'' Her highest-profile show in the theater district was ''Fela!'': she served as associate director during the end of its Broadway run.
docs.abstract: Patricia McGregor takes 'big leap' as director of Katori Hall's Hurt Village, part of the inaugural season of the new Signature Theater complex. Photo (M)

docs.snippet: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 84TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS The tried-and-true Billy Crystal returns for his ninth stint as host of this ceremony broadcast live from the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles (above, setting the scene). George Clooney is up for best act...
docs.lead_paragraph: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 84TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS The tried-and-true Billy Crystal returns for his ninth stint as host of this ceremony broadcast live from the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles (above, setting the scene). George Clooney is up for best actor for ''The Descendants,'' but oddsmakers are predicting that Jean Dujardin will take home the Oscar for his role as a silent-movie star in ''The Artist,'' the black-and-white tribute to a golden age in Hollywood. That film is expected to win best picture as well, while its director, Michel Hazanavicius, is favored for the directing award. Viola Davis is the top best-actress contender for her turn as a courageous maid in ''The Help,'' though Meryl Streep, as Margaret Thatcher in ''The Iron Lady,'' could make it a close race. And in the best-supporting category, Christopher Plummer is expected to win as a father who comes out of the closet near the end of his life in ''Beginners,'' as is Octavia Spencer, who portrayed another determined maid in ''The Help.'' ''A Separation,'' the domestic drama set in Iran, is favored to win for best foreign film. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 4 on the TV Guide Channel; and at 6 on Channel 11. Tim Gunn, Robin Roberts, Jess Cagle, Nina Garcia and Louise Roe interview celebrities on the red carpet at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E! 7 A.M. (Sho2) THE KING'S SPEECH (2010) Colin Firth, below, in the role for which he won the best-actor Oscar last year, portrays Albert Frederick Arthur George, or Bertie, as his family called him, the shy second son of George V of Britain (Michael Gambon) in this film from Tom Hooper. Geoffrey Rush is Lionel Logue, the speech therapist who helps him conquer his debilitating stutter. And Helena Bonham Carter is Elizabeth, Bertie's wife and staunch support system, who can't quite stomach Wallis Simpson (Eve Best), the American divorcée who leads Bertie's older brother, David (Guy Pearce), to abdicate as Edward VIII. ''It isn't exactly 'Pygmalion,' not least because Mr. Hooper has no intention of satirizing the caste system that is one of this movie's biggest draws,'' Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, said of the film, which received 12 nominations and earned Mr. Hooper an Oscar as best director. ''Like many entertainments of this pop-historical type, 'The King's Speech' wears history lightly no matter how heavy the crown.'' The film also won Academy Awards for best picture and original screenplay (David Seidler).

docs.snippet: Courgartown, Utah; Gehry vs. Ike; and the transgender defender....
docs.abstract: One Page Magazine features a profile of longtime Martin Scorsese editor Thelma Schoonmaker, an analysis of the controversy over the Frank Gehry Eisenhower Memorial, and tips from Stedman Graham on how to be an independent man. Drawings, Photos, Charts (M)1
